query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Io non m’accorsi del salire in ella; 14 ma d’esservi entro mi fé assai fede 15 la donna mia ch’i’ vidi far più bella.
query.result:
**English:**
13 I did not notice the ascent into it; 14 but that I was inside gave me ample proof 15 my lady whom I saw become more beautiful.
**Cornish:**
13 Vyth na vyth gweles an sevel ynno; 14 mes bos an bewnans vyth ynno a wrug 15 an vrassa vyth a weles ow tos ha bos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 E come in fiamma favilla si vede, 17 e come in voce voce si discerne, 18 quand’ una è ferma e altra va e riede,
19 vid’ io in essa luce altre lucerne 20 muoversi in giro più e men correnti, 21 al modo, credo, di lor viste interne.
query.result:
**English:**
16 And as a spark is seen in a flame, 17 and as a voice is discerned in a voice, 18 when one is steady and the other goes and returns,
19 I saw in that light other lights 20 moving in a circle, faster and slower, 21 in the manner, I believe, of their inner visions.
**Cornish:**
16 Ha dellvel dellow avel yn flamen, 17 ha dellvel leow avel yn leow, 18 pan vo unn stevel ha'n aral a wra ha dyllo,
19 me a weles ynno golow erel erel 20 ow tos ow tos moy ha moy tyn, 21 yn an fordh, yth kregaf, a'ga golwgow diwotti.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Di fredda nube non disceser venti, 23 o visibili o no, tanto festini, 24 che non paressero impediti e lenti
25 a chi avesse quei lumi divini 26 veduti a noi venir, lasciando il giro 27 pria cominciato in li alti Serafini;
28 e dentro a quei che più innanzi appariro 29 sonava ‘Osanna’ sì, che unque poi 30 di rïudir non fui sanza disiro.
query.result:
**English:**
22 From a cold cloud no winds descended, 23 visible or not, so swift, 24 that they would not have seemed impeded and slow
25 to one who had seen those divine lights 26 come toward us, leaving the circle 27 first begun among the high Seraphim;
28 and within those that appeared in front 29 resounded "Hosanna" so that never after 30 was I without the desire to hear it again.
**Cornish:**
22 Dhyworth klowd yen na dethens gwynsow, 23 gweladow po nag, kemmys fest, 24 na wra yns gwelys ow lettya ha dow,
25 dhe unn a via gweles an golow divin 26 ow tos dhe'n ni, ow kensa an gylgh 27 kyns o commensys gans an Seraphyn ughel;
28 ha diwotti dhe'n re beu a dheuth yn kyns 29 o sonya 'Osanna' mar, wosa henna 30 vyth vyth heb an dysyr dhe'y glywys arta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Indi si fece l’un più presso a noi 32 e solo incominciò: «Tutti sem presti 33 al tuo piacer, perché di noi ti gioi.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Then one of them drew nearer to us 32 and began to speak alone: "We are all ready 33 to do your bidding, because you take joy in us.
**Cornish:**
31 Wosa henna unn a wrug moy dhe'n ni 32 ha ow dalleth ow tos: "Nebes oll prest 33 dhe'th bleser, rag orth agan ty a wra lowen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Noi ci volgiam coi principi celesti 35 d’un giro e d’un girare e d’una sete, 36 ai quali tu del mondo già dicesti:
37 ‘Voi che ’ntendendo il terzo ciel movete’; 38 e sem sì pien d’amor, che, per piacerti, 39 non fia men dolce un poco di quïete».
query.result:
**English:**
34 We revolve with the celestial princes 35 in one gyre, one revolution, and one desire, 36 to whom you once said of the world:
37 "You who, in understanding, move the third heaven"; 38 and we are so full of love that, to please you, 39 a little rest will not be less sweet."
**Cornish:**
34 Ni a wra ow treylya gans an prinsiplys nevek 35 a unn gylgh, unn troyl, ha unn syth, 36 dhe'n re ty a leveris a'n bys:
37 'Hwi a wra ow movyas an tresves nef'; 38 ha ni a wra kemmys leun a garow, rag orth agan pleser, 39 na wra moy dowl unn byghan a hedh'.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Poscia che li occhi miei si fuoro offerti 41 a la mia donna reverenti, ed essa 42 fatti li avea di sé contenti e certi,
43 rivolsersi a la luce che promessa 44 tanto s’avea, e «Deh, chi siete?» fue 45 la voce mia di grande affetto impressa.
query.result:
**English:**
40 After my eyes had been offered 41 to my lady with reverence, and she 42 had made them content and certain of her,
43 they turned to the light that had promised 44 itself so much, and "Oh, who are you?" was 45 my voice, marked with great affection.
**Cornish:**
40 Wosa henna ow lagha o via offrys 41 dhe'm vrassa gans reverens, ha henna 42 a wra ow gwreys kontent ha sur,
43 yns treylyas dhe'n golow a via promisys 44 kemmys moy, ha "Ow, pyth yw hwi?" o via 45 ow leow gans affection bras.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 E quanta e quale vid’ io lei far piùe 47 per allegrezza nova che s’accrebbe, 48 quando parlai, a l’allegrezze sue!
49 Così fatta, mi disse: «Il mondo m’ebbe 50 giù poco tempo; e se più fosse stato, 51 molto sarà di mal, che non sarebbe.
query.result:
**English:**
46 And how much and how greatly I saw her grow 47 in new joy that increased 48 when I spoke, to her joys!
49 Thus made, she said to me: "The world had me 50 below for a short time; and if I had stayed longer, 51 there would be much evil that would not be.
**Cornish:**
46 Ha pyth moy ha pyth bras a weles vyth ow tos moy 47 rag lowena nowydh a wra ow kreski, 48 pan wrelloth, dhe'y lowenow!
49 Mar ow tos gwreys, henna a leveris dhe'm: "An bys a via 50 vyth issel rag termyn byghan; ha po vyth moy, 51 moy a via moy a dhreus, na wra vyth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 La mia letizia mi ti tien celato 53 che mi raggia dintorno e mi nasconde 54 quasi animal di sua seta fasciato.
query.result:
**English:**
52 My joy keeps me hidden from you, 53 which radiates around me and conceals me, 54 like an animal wrapped in its silk.
**Cornish:**
52 Ow lowena a wra ow tos ow kelmys 53 a wra ow ragya owtro ha ow kudha 54 dellvel eneval fascys yn y seta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Assai m’amasti, e avesti ben onde; 56 che s’io fossi giù stato, io ti mostrava 57 di mio amor più oltre che le fronde.
query.result:
**English:**
55 You loved me greatly, and you had good reason; 56 for if I had stayed below, I would have shown you 57 of my love more than the leaves.
**Cornish:**
55 Moy a via ow karas moy, ha ty a via dell rag; 56 rag po vyth vyth issel, vyth a wra ow tos 57 a'th karantek moy moy es an frondow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Quella sinistra riva che si lava 59 di Rodano poi ch’è misto con Sorga, 60 per suo segnore a tempo m’aspettava,
61 e quel corno d’Ausonia che s’imborga 62 di Bari e di Gaeta e di Catona, 63 da ove Tronto e Verde in mare sgorga.
query.result:
**English:**
58 That sinister shore that is washed 59 by the Rhône after it has mingled with the Sorgue, 60 awaited me in due time as its lord,
61 and that horn of Ausonia which adorns itself 62 with Bari and Gaeta and Catona, 63 from where the Tronto and the Verde flow into the sea.
**Cornish:**
58 An fordh-nans yw henna a wra woles 59 gans an Rodan wosa kesmes gans an Sorga, 60 a wra'm golow orth yn y eur,
61 ha'n horn-nans Ausonia henna a wra'n golow 62 gans Bari ha Gaeta ha Catona, 63 a-dhyworth yma Tronto ha Verde a wra'n golan dhe'n mor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Fulgeami già in fronte la corona 65 di quella terra che ’l Danubio riga 66 poi che le ripe tedesche abbandona.
query.result:
**English:**
64 The crown of that land which the Danube irrigates 65 was already shining on my brow, 66 after it abandons the German banks.
**Cornish:**
64 O goth genes yn-mronn an corona 65 a'n tir-nans henna a wra'n dowr gans an Danubio 66 wosa e hwra'n an glannow Almayn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 E la bella Trinacria, che caliga 68 tra Pachino e Peloro, sopra ’l golfo 69 che riceve da Euro maggior briga,
70 non per Tifeo ma per nascente solfo, 71 attesi avrebbe li suoi regi ancora, 72 nati per me di Carlo e di Ridolfo,
73 se mala segnoria, che sempre accora 74 li popoli suggetti, non avesse 75 mosso Palermo a gridar: “Mora, mora!”.
query.result:
**English:**
67 And fair Trinacria, which lies hidden 68 between Pachino and Peloro, above the gulf 69 which receives the greatest force from the east wind,
70 not because of Typhon but because of the rising sulphur, 71 would still be awaiting its kings, 72 born for me from Charles and Rudolph,
73 if bad governance, which always grieves 74 the subject peoples, had not 75 stirred up Palermo to cry: “Death, death!”.
**Cornish:**
67 Ha Trinacria brav, henna a wra kudhys 68 ynter Pachino ha Peloro, a-ugh an golf 69 a wra'n resevya an brassa moyha gans an Euros,
70 nyns drefen Tifeo mes drefen an solfor a wra'n kres, 71 a wra'n golow orth y reysow ytho, 72 genys ragof dhyworth Charles ha Ridolfo,
73 mes an governans drog, henna a wra'n gordh bys vyth, 74 an bobel a wra'n sojet, nyns o devrew 75 Palermo dhe greghya: “Mara, mara!”.

**English:**
76 And if my brother foresaw this, 77 the avaricious poverty of Catalonia 78 would already be fleeing, so that it would not harm them;
79 for truly it is necessary to provide 80 for him, or for someone else, so that his boat 81 laden with more cargo does not sink.
**Cornish:**
76 Ha'n frer vyth a welo henna, 77 an boverta avarij a Gatalunya 78 a wra'n fugi bys vyth, rag na wra'n offendy,
79 rag gwir yn-mes a wra reydh provy, 80 rag ev, po rag neb aral, dhe wul henna 81 karges gans moy cargo nyns o pogna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 La sua natura, che di larga parca 83 discese, avria mestier di tal milizia 84 che non curasse di mettere in arca».
query.result:
**English:**
82 His nature, which descended from a generous Parca, 83 would have need of such a militia 84 that would not care to put money in the chest.
**Cornish:**
82 Y natur ev, a wra dallethys gans Parca brav, 83 a wra'n mester a'n milita henna 84 na wra'n ow keskar dhe gorra yn-mes yn an archa».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 «Però ch’i’ credo che l’alta letizia 86 che ’l tuo parlar m’infonde, segnor mio, 87 là ’ve ogne ben si termina e s’inizia,
88 per te si veggia come la vegg’ io, 89 grata m’è più; e anco quest’ ho caro 90 perché ’l discerni rimirando in Dio.
query.result:
**English:**
85 “However, because I believe that the great joy 86 which your speech infuses in me, my lord, 87 there where every good thing ends and begins,
88 may be seen by you as I see it, 89 it is more pleasing to me; and I also hold this dear 90 because you discern it by looking at God.
**Cornish:**
85 “Mes rag yma y’m krys y letis bras 86 henna a wra'n yth gorra yth lavar, syr vyth, 87 ena yma pub tra a wra dallethys ha gorfen,
88 rag ty vyth yma ytho y weles ytho, 89 moy brav yw dhe'm; ha henna yw kerys vyth 90 rag yma ytho yth weles ow kesmus yn Duw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Fatto m’hai lieto, e così mi fa chiaro, 92 poi che, parlando, a dubitar m’hai mosso 93 com’ esser può, di dolce seme, amaro».
query.result:
**English:**
91 You have made me glad, and thus you make it clear to me, 92 since, by speaking, you have moved me to doubt 93 how it can be that from sweet seed comes bitterness.
**Cornish:**
91 Yth wra'm gweles lowen, ha henna yw gweles kler dhe'm, 92 wosa, ow leverel, yth wra'm movy dhe ammeth 93 pyth yll bos, a hadow brav, fethow feth.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Questo io a lui; ed elli a me: «S’io posso 95 mostrarti un vero, a quel che tu dimandi 96 terrai lo viso come tien lo dosso.
query.result:
**English:**
94 This I said to him; and he to me: “If I can 95 show you a truth, to that which you ask 96 you will turn your face as you turn your back.
**Cornish:**
94 Henna vyth dhe'v; ha henna dhe'm: “Mar y’m gallos 95 mos dhiso gwir, dhe henna pyth yma owth gorra 96 yth wra'th gorra yth wylas pyth yth dorn.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Lo ben che tutto il regno che tu scandi 98 volge e contenta, fa esser virtute 99 sua provedenza in questi corpi grandi.
query.result:
**English:**
97 The good which revolves and satisfies the entire kingdom 98 over which you wander, makes its providence 99 to be virtue in these great bodies.
**Cornish:**
97 An da yw gorra ha sodho an oll an ryes 98 pyth yma yth kerdhes, yw gweles y virtu 99 y brovyans yn-mes yn an korfow brav ma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 E non pur le nature provedute 101 sono in la mente ch’è da sé perfetta, 102 ma esse insieme con la lor salute:
103 per che quantunque quest’ arco saetta 104 disposto cade a proveduto fine, 105 sì come cosa in suo segno diretta.
query.result:
**English:**
100 And not only are the natures provided for 101 in the mind which is perfect in itself, 102 but also their well-being:
103 because however much this bow shoots 104 it falls disposed to a provided end, 105 just like something directed at its target.
**Cornish:**
100 Ha nyns es an naturys provyys yn-mes 101 yn-mes yn an menes henna yw perthfek yn-hi, 102 mes ytho gans aga helh:
103 rag pub tra veth an bow ma ow setha 104 ytho yw dallethys dhe fin provyys, 105 kepar ha tra owth gorra dhe'y merk.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Vuo’ tu che questo ver più ti s’imbianchi?». 113 E io: «Non già; ché impossibil veggio 114 che la natura, in quel ch’è uopo, stanchi».
query.result:
**English:**
112 Do you want this truth to become clearer to you? 113 And I: “Not at all; for I see it is impossible 114 that nature, in what is necessary, should grow weary.”
**Cornish:**
112 A wra’th ow tos owth usya gwell dhe dhysky? 113 Ha my: “Nyns yw; rag gweles impossibyl 114 bos dhe natur, yn hy yw rekis, dhe vos rudh.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Ond’ elli ancora: «Or dì: sarebbe il peggio 116 per l’omo in terra, se non fosse cive?». 117 «Sì», rispuos’ io; «e qui ragion non cheggio».
query.result:
**English:**
115 And he again: “Now tell me: would it be worse 116 for man on earth, if he were not a citizen?” 117 “Yes,” I replied; “and here I ask no reasons.”
**Cornish:**
115 Mes ef a leveris: “Wruthylla bos gwell 116 dhe’n den war an nor, mar nadhvia kethiver?” 117 “Yow,” gorra vy; “ha yma nyns wra vy gowes.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 «E puot’ elli esser, se giù non si vive 119 diversamente per diversi offici? 120 Non, se ’l maestro vostro ben vi scrive».
query.result:
**English:**
118 “And can it be, if down below one does not live 119 differently according to different offices? 120 Not, if your master writes well for you.”
**Cornish:**
118 “Ha gallos possybyl, mar nyns yw bewnans 119 yn kethiver dre wosa dyffrans? 120 Nyns yw, mar owth mester a skrif yn ta.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Sì venne deducendo infino a quici; 122 poscia conchiuse: «Dunque esser diverse 123 convien di vostri effetti le radici:
124 per ch’un nasce Solone e altro Serse, 125 altro Melchisedèch e altro quello 126 che, volando per l’aere, il figlio perse.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Thus he came deducing down to this point; 122 then he concluded: “Therefore the roots 123 of your effects must be diverse:
124 for which reason one is born Solon and another Xerxes, 125 another Melchizedek and another he 126 who, flying through the air, lost his son.
**Cornish:**
121 Ythoma dhe dhuktya bys dhe’n poynt ma; 122 wosa henna a leveris: “Rag hemma, bos dyffrans 123 dhe wradhow dhe’w effeythow:
124 rag henna onan yw genys Solon ha Serse aral, 125 Melkisedek aral ha’n aral henna 126 a golla yn ayr, a gollas y vab.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 La circular natura, ch’è suggello 128 a la cera mortal, fa ben sua arte, 129 ma non distingue l’un da l’altro ostello.
query.result:
**English:**
127 The circular nature, which is the seal 128 on the mortal wax, does its work well, 129 but it does not distinguish one dwelling from another.
**Cornish:**
127 An natur kelghynnus, syw’n sel 128 war an waks mortal, a wra y ober yn ta, 129 mes nyns yw dyffransya onan chy an aral.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Quinci addivien ch’Esaù si diparte 131 per seme da Iacòb; e vien Quirino 132 da sì vil padre, che si rende a Marte.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Hence it comes that Esau departs 131 by seed from Jacob; and Quirinus comes 132 from a father so vile that he yields to Mars.
**Cornish:**
130 Dre henna yw Esaù ow parti 131 dre hadow dhyworth Iakòb; ha Quirinus a dheu 132 dhyworth tas avel, may hy a omdhrevi dhe Mars.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Natura generata il suo cammino 134 simil farebbe sempre a’ generanti, 135 se non vincesse il proveder divino.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Generated nature would always make its course 134 similar to the generators, 135 if divine providence did not prevail.
**Cornish:**
133 An natur genys a wra y fordh sempel 134 ow kul an genysoryon, 135 mar nadhvia an ragprovians Divin a wra gwell.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Or quel che t’era dietro t’è davanti: 137 ma perché sappi che di te mi giova, 138 un corollario voglio che t’ammanti.
query.result:
**English:**
136 Now what was behind you is before you: 137 but so that you may know that I take pleasure in you, 138 I want you to cherish a corollary.
**Cornish:**
136 Mes an pyth ovia war’th kler a’th omma 137 mes rag bos dhe dhysky bos ow tos ow lowena, 138 ow tos owth korolari dhe dhe dhysky owth karga.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Sempre natura, se fortuna trova 140 discorde a sé, com’ ogne altra semente 141 fuor di sua regïon, fa mala prova.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Nature always, if it finds fortune 140 discordant with itself, like any other seed 141 outside its own region, makes a poor showing.
**Cornish:**
139 Natur sempel, mar kavos fortun 140 ynkord dhe hy honan, kepar pub hadow aral 141 mes yma dhe’y rannvro, a wra provadh drok.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 E se ’l mondo là giù ponesse mente 143 al fondamento che natura pone, 144 seguendo lui, avria buona la gente.
query.result:
**English:**
142 And if the world down there paid attention 143 to the foundation that nature lays, 144 following it, the people would be good.
**Cornish:**
142 Ha'gas an bys y'nwedhen vyth poynt 143 dhe'n fordh a wra nessa poos, 144 ow kul an pobel vyth da.
